SO MOE!!!....or so it would appear. Not sure what it literally means to be MOE!!! but anyway...
Let me begin by saying that Romance was never my favorite genre or at least it never occurred to me that the genre would become my favorite. And as I was searching for more anime that would be related to Romance, I happened to come across this gem of an anime. 
Kaichou Wa Maid Sama...An anime about school and maids? Sure it sounds pretty dumb at first and you'd think it's like every other anime with butlers and maids but it's NOT! KWMS is actually a heartwarming anime aboutlove and of the walls people need to overcome to reach what we call love. 


From the story to the characters, you'll fall in love with the anime...however you'll feel disheartened by the end knowing that you've gone through all the episodes and you want more! The story is basically about a female character who falls in love with a guy who has a mysterious background that you won't find out about unless you read the manga beyond the anime...which you should do anyway, because it's a beautiful story really. Along the way, our heroine and hero expresses each others love in different ways...but pride gets in the way and walls begin to arise which complicates the already complex relationship. 


It's a love story, and it's worth your time if you're in to romance or even if you're not - just try it. You might end up loving it as much as I have, which i'd never thought would be possible. It will make you laugh, give you the warm fuzzy feeling in your heart, and eventually will make you fall in love with it.

If you enjoy a good tsundere-romance anime with the main protaganist being being a girl who is good at doing everything she does but is actually working hard for it, look no further. I do not know how many times i have re-watched this anime because the plot is really good and i really love a good romance anime without the girl being too direct about her feelings(tsundere) and that the guy who fell in love with her is so perfect (what every guy wishes to be kind) makes this anime in the top of my list for romance.It does have a moderate build upto the relationship status but in the end a conclusion was inevitable in this anime and it did deliver.

*My first review ever!!*
Here we have another romantic anime... The best looking, hardest working girl in the school coupled with the most handsome guy in the school. Pretty generic story line but what made this anime stand out was its delivery.
The story line is nothing special. In fact, it is very predictable. We have our two main protagonists attracted to each other (but Usui finds the attraction first) and they go through many adventures to realize their feelings for one another. There are not many moments where you feel that a story arc is a filler; each story builds upon the relationship between Usui andMasaki. There are some ridiculous moments where Usui saves Masaki that is absolutely impossible in real life but I would give the anime some slack. These impossible moments, in a way, makes you feel closer to their relationship and even root for them to be together.


The art is solid. When I saw the poster, I was hesitant in watching it because it had Misaki sport a Luffy look and I don't like that style of artwork. But in the anime, Misaki is drawn in a totally different style and it's the kind of artwork that I like. The "dreamy" scenes are captured in slow-mo and are absolutely hilarious to watch. Sometimes, the art work for Usui changes to have him look very small and cute (I'm kinda new to shoujo anime so I'm not sure if this is a characteristic of this genre) and it really reflects the light-hearted atmosphere. 


The sound is where Maid-Sama falls a bit short. It's not terrible but it's not incredible. There is this one upbeat theme that repeats over and over again whenever Misaki gets some determination. When the first time you hear it, it's pretty exciting but after 30 or so times, your ears will tire out. But the opening and ending songs are fantastic and for me, that's what redeems the sound in this anime.


The entire cast is absolutely charming. We have Usui, the cool, protective, stalkerish boyfriend, and Misaki, the girl who is strong-willed and refuses to recognize her feelings. These two make a really great duo and you really want them to be together at the end. My favourite secondary characters were Minako, Misaki's sister, and the fanboy trio who follows Misaki everywhere. Misaki's sister doesn't say anything funny but her quirkiness is one component of the comic relief. The fanboy trio is a really cute bunch and are also part of the comic relief.


I absolutely enjoyed this anime and it is no surprise that it is on the top of many YouTube best romance anime videos. Definitely do give this anime a look!

So let's get this straight. As a guy, the main character Misaki is cute as hell. Especially when she blushes, and is wearing a maid-fuku! As far as it goes for moe-characters, she is a 24 carat diamond. However, i must admit that it's not competitive enough to break out of the shoujo fanbase.
Story: 7
It's innovative enough, but not exactly anything new. The story is also full of loopholes probably designed to appeal to female fans. It is also very shallow and focuses on nothing but gags and blushes. It never gives you room to seriously think about the main character's problems and about relationships,an absolute opposite of many shoujo animes.


Art: 6

It's not that terrible that it's intolerable, but it really makes you wonder if they're really that short on money. Well, at least the maid-fukus are cute enough.


Sound: 6

Nothing really stands out, but not terrible either.


Character: 7 

There's a lot of character in this anime. Most of the mains are unique enough, but don't have enough depth and background to justify their un-human incredibility.


Enjoyment: 8

If it needs to be said, this anime is very much made just for the fun of it. It's just great to watch a cute tsundere in a maid-fuku blushing at the molestations of a bishounen, and that's very much all that counts.


Overall: 7

Not exactly good enough to be a gem in the rotting industry, but it's moe enough to keep me watching.

Truly one of the most abhorrent things related to romance I've ever seen, this poor excuse of a TV show is truly why we can't have nice things here in the weeb world. 
A prime example of absolutely everything any normal anime or ANY piece of media of romantic nature shouldn't do, it starts on an "amusing" ( at best ) concept worth three minutes of comical screen time, only to turn out to be literally nothing more than that, with the rest of the 25 episodes rehashing basically the same plot of other any other cliche-filled anime there is, and kind of applying itsterrible premise at it. It's not really taking any time to justify or explain the utterly dumb progress it thinks it has - the basic plot is all there is, and then the oh-so-funny shenanigans ensue. Furthermore, rather than like a comedy or a romance, it feels like a simply bad experience for its own characters and viewers all the same. The only person aside from the actual audience who seemingly enjoyed the plot going on is the the male love interest, and his character is about as flat as a loli.


And what better combo than cardboard characters featuring in a classic story of a harassing romance! You know it can't be true love if it ain't forced here among weebs, and such is the case here too - far too many questionable actions and words, far too much cringe, if I really have to use that word. Additionally, with the main girl's position as a "maid waifu", she is truly nothing more than yet another romantic pursuit to be "owned", as is the tradition with these things - the male MC really isn't trying to hide this, clearly enjoying the fact he can use the girl MC's secret to his own sick advantage, even if it's just to tease her.


In a long run, there is really no actual development outside of new, equally as cardboard-ish characters coming into the, khm, "plot".


You might be thinking "but Reviewer! There are thing happening in this anime, don't you remember the this and the that? The festival and the trip?" but truly, any sort of "arcs" or "plots" this anime thinks is working on are ultimately so irrelevant and forgettable in the face of the main two character being pretty and cool and in love, which seems to be a selling point for most of equally empty romance titles. 


This one is no exception.

I picked up this show because I was in the mood for a romance anime and it had a good rating. Unfortunately, this anime was pretty disappointing and it really doesn’t live up to its rating. I would suggest you go elsewhere for your fix of romance if that's what you're looking for, because what exists of a payoff just isn't worth the painfully boring and contrived story, plus every other problem with the series. 
The beginning was promising and exciting. Here we had this atypical female protagonist who subverted tropes and was confident, headstrong, and borderline tyrannical in her student council president role. AlthoughAyuzawa is perfect to the point of being a Mary Sue (amazing at academics, sports, beauty, is the student council prez, etc.), it was excusable because the exaggeratedness of her character was comical but also because her interesting secret identity added something unique to her character in that she had something to hide. The duality in her character was a gap moe in itself, which was charming. Then we had the aloof Usui, the Gary Stu to her Mary Sue (equally amazing at academics, sports, beauty, etc.), but what made him subversive and interesting to watch was that he wore his heart on his sleeve, making it instantly clear that he was romantically interested in Ayuzawa from the get-go. So the first few episodes were really great-- exactly what I was looking for, and I watched on happily for a while, satisfied with the two cute main characters and their dynamic. But from about the middle of the anime and onwards, it went downhill at an increasingly rapid speed. 


The main problems were the characters and the story. I won’t go into too much detail regarding the story, but I will say that there basically isn’t one… which isn’t a good look. The absence of plot becomes an increasingly painful flaw as the series goes on. However, what exists of a story is essentially a series of contrived scenarios where suspension of disbelief progressively becomes impossible and the people act in more and more aggravatingly stupid ways.


I will go into depth regarding the characters though. First- the supporting cast. The side characters were non-descript and one-dimensional from the beginning, but could even have been considered charming at their best. Ayuzawa's friends, her coworkers, her sister, the delinquents-turned-fanboys, etc. - all were alright in that they were supportive of her, although they unfortunately had no depth. They served their purpose as whatever they were, but that was REALLY as far as it went. This could have been rectified as the series went on given the hefty 26 episodes allotted, but they really just... did nothing with these characters, the ENTIRE TIME. It was as if the series was in stasis for the whole series. Nobody changed at all, nobody became more interesting. The most we got was the delinquents-turned-fanboys' past being revealed, but even that ended up having the depth of a kiddie pool. I had hopes for Aoi too, but after the initial reveal/twist in this character, they remained as shallow as the rest of them. It was impossible to see these characters as anything more than one-dimensional caricatures. Not a single one of those characters ended up seeming like an actual human being, which made the series eventually unbearable for me by the mid-endpoint.


As for the mains, it was actually exactly the same. They're cute together... but the stagnation of their relationship as well as the stagnation of every other character eventually bogs you down enough that it's no longer enjoyable to watch them together. 


[SPOILERS, somewhat]


It gets really boring. Usui jumps in and saves Ayuzawa over and over again, and Ayuzawa's feelings towards Usui progress at a snail's pace, if even. She obviously likes him. You can see that in how much she relies on him and inadvertently cries out to him for help in times of crisis. But Usui is literally coming to see her at every waking moment of his life and by episode 19, we still haven't seen her return even a fraction of the care Usui has done for her. I want to make it clear that she is not obliged to return his feelings nor all the favors he's done for her, but I wouldn't even treat a friend this apathetically when this friend is taking THAT much time out of their day for you. If someone is pouring in this much effort and time into being with you while you are not, that is something that has to be addressed. Are you two on the same page? By that I mean, are they okay with you not being as proactive in the relationship as they are? Are they in love with you? If they are, do you feel the same way that they do? Because if you don't, then their continued investment in you is clearly a problem and is unfair to the other party. And so on. This goes unaddressed the whole time, which is the main problem with their relationship. Usui is clearly in love with her and she clearly values him too... and yet, there is this discrepancy in the way they treat each other. He invests a ridiculous amount of time in their relationship, initiating almost every interaction/time they spend together while she... does not, which makes their relationship feel imbalanced at best, and injust at worst. 


One more thing that I think is important to address, at least briefly, are some of the problematic elements in the show. At first, it was minor enough for me to be able to put it aside, acknowledge that what was wrong, and keep watching, but the whole thing with Aoi at the beach was my breaking point. The problematic element that stuck out to me the most at the beginning was Ayuzawa being physically assaulted and threatened by the two men who broke into the maid café and how they played that for laughs. These are serious crimes that were committed by the two men with real repercussions for the victim, and they basically brushed it off with a sex joke-- about them being masochists searching for a dominatrix, and called it a day from there. Needless to say, that depiction was problematic. The other incident I need to talk about is the whole dynamic between Aoi, his aunt, and his father, and what went down at the beach with his aunt. Nobody finds it fucked up or even comments on the fact that the aunt proposes some ridiculous bet, saying that he has to win a contest to prove his “masculinity” to his father in order to be allowed to dress the way he wants to. He is constantly pushed by his family members to be more “like a boy”, or “act more like a man”. Who’s to say he has to rigidly fit in one category? Why is he forced to stop dressing in a way that makes him feel confidently himself and secure in his identity? When Aoi staunchly says he feels the most comfortable and like himself when he dresses femininely and that he was happy to do that even if everyone shunned him for it, his aunt thinks to herself, “He truly has a man’s spirit!”, in reference to his adamancy. Caught up in pushing Aoi into what she defines the category of “boy”, she doesn’t even stop to think that if she cared about her nephew at all, she would listen to what he was saying. But that would mean considering his feelings for just one second, which is a degree of empathy and depth that is unthinkable for any of these characters.


What it really comes down to is that 2/3 of the way, the show was unwatchable for me which is why I dropped it. It was people I didn't care about doing things I  didn't care about while supporting characters that I didn't care about filled up space. As far as genres go, it failed in every respect. 

- Comedy: the show had lost all of its comedic value after the first 10 episodes, if I were to estimate. Probably because of how badly contrived the scenarios were, and not in a humorous way at all (just one e.g. of this story that I didn't mention before: really? that butler arc? So boring I started skipping through it. Nonsense scenarios, with literally no stakes, for nonsense characters. That was a major letdown)

- Romance/Shoujo: I didn't feel a single spark by that point in the series. Even if Usui is doing the most, it's hard to gush over an imbalanced, borderline toxic relationship between characters who show no sign of growth-- especially Ayuzawa, and she's our protagonist... so that's a negative to say the least.


Overall, it’s a 6/10, although after writing this review I wonder if even that is too high. [Edit: I've since changed it to 5/10 accordingly.] This has become far longer than I expected, but hopefully this review can be useful to even one person. Thanks for reading this far!

Well here 8 years removed, I doubt I’ll find anywhere near an attentive audience, but I felt compelled to write a review. And for the first time ever, I felt compelled to write an unfavorable review. Maybe it’s too edgy to write a poor review for a cult popular show like Maid-sama, but here I go. 
As a side note, I understand that certain anime are tailored toward certain audiences, and I’m not a teenage girl. Even still, I sought this anime out with a positive mindset and with many pros, and instead left with many criticisms. Don’t watch High School DxD if you can’thandle Ecchi and don’t watch Eromanga Sensei if you dislike incest portrayed in anime. But if you come into a romance anime with a profile that is highly comprised of school romances, you bet I can tell the good from the bad. 


I will now proceed to review by MyAnimeList’s listed order:


Story (4/10)

The story, well isn’t really. And that’s okay for something like this, but it needs to make up with other things, which I’ll get into later. Instead, going by premise, the main character is the student council president, feminist, poor, and works at a maid cafe. Hot, cool guy enters and romance ensues. I’ll include recommendations or alternatives at the end, I’m done with the story. 


Art (5/10)

There is nothing inventive about the art. On a scale from Kanon (2002) to Kyoto Animation or Makoto Shinkai, this is like normal 2000s art. There was nothing special about anything to the art. Watching it for 26 episodes really made me realize why it’s either really important to have a good story to back up marginal art or make the anime really pretty. It wasn’t bad and I want to get this weird taste out of my mouth with some beautiful Kyoto animation, so I’ll just slap a 5 on there and move on. 


Sound (7/10)

Hey, it’s the only thing I gave better than the overall score! Obviously based on averages this is saving the score a little bit, but why? It’s because I’m a weeb that’s far past help, and fanboy over voice actors. Kana Hanazawa is the leading voice actor for a reason. Aki Toyasaki is another popular voice actor that I just caught onto at the right time, which is fortunate for this anime. I thought it was strange how it reused voice actors for other roles (I counted Kana Hanazawa at least 3 Different characters and Aki Toyosaki at least 2 different characters) but I will always accept listening to Kana Hanazawa voice more. OP is ok, other sound is ok. Sound is probably good for a 5 and 2 extra for voice actors bias. 


Characters (4/10)

I introduced Misaki and Usui in the story portion (because there isn’t a story to talk about) but that’s basically it. I didn’t feel any sort of character development from them passed what they were described as. In fact, I felt the side characters move more overall by the end than they did. Very generic, and while that’s passable, they continued to ruin it until there were only bad stereotypes left. The only thing good about these characters are their voice actors as mentioned above. 


Enjoyment (3/10)

Can you guess what gave it a 3/10? I bet you probably could, if you actually read up until here. If you guessed, “enjoyment rose exponentially every time Kana Hanazawa or Aki Toyosaki spoke” then you would be correct! Of course, that doesn’t always save a series as I can get that same voice from listening to renai circulation on repeat for hours on end. I was so unentertained that while I was watching this in class, it almost inspired me to stop watching anime and pay attention to my AP Chemistry teacher talk about gasses and Avogadro’s hyptohesis. Then, they continued to drag me through this *expletive* for 26 episodes at snail’s pace. Trust me, I am ok with slow pacing and long 20+ episode series, but this torture was the first anime I actively disliked for a 20+ episode series. 


Overall (5/10)

The best thing about this is surviving it. And the voice actors. I could have been watching cute girls doing cute things or maybe a romantic comedy, but this was about the worst thing that could happen to me. If you liked this series (I only judge silently) then I recommend “Special A” which is the same things about the female MC romance with Hot guy cool and good at everything saving the day, except not terrible. You can also try EVERY OTHER SHOUJO ANIME ABOUT A GIRL AND A HOT GUY like maybe “Kimi ni Todoke” or even better, “Inu x boku ss.” I know older romances like “welcome to the nhk” or “bakuman” can be good, but this one should be forgotten.

NOTE: I ain't no english speaker
A friend of mine reccommended me Maid-Sama! and since I was planing on watching it anyway I decided to go along and get to it. I had a mix of expectations. On one hand I knew that this was going to be just another highschool rom-com with tear-jerking and melodrama. On the other hand the premise seemed more interesting than most and the overall charm of the anime hooked me. In any case, I was expecting an enjoyable watch.
I must gladly say that my expectations were not only fulfilled, but the anime managed to impress me.
PRODUCTION VALUE
The production is simple,but it works. The art is quite unique with the characters and scenarios, and the overall look of the series having their own charm. It's nothing out of the ordinary though but surely the colorful look of the show stands out in the crowd, even if it is a little "too colorful". The animation was more impressive than other anime of the same style. It was consistent and it never fell down hard due to budget (or at least it wasn't noticeable).\n
As for the sound, it was good but just like the art/animation it wasn't great. The voice acting was well done and overall the anime sounded clear and nice. The soundtrack is forgettable. Not much to say about it.\n\n
STORY\n
Although the premise is cliched, it was interesting enough for me to care about the anime and I was specially glad at the fact that the anime didn't use a tear-jerking approach nor teen-agnst. This is basically a rom-com and as one it is entertaining and it delivers good humour and a satisfactory relationship building...for the most part...It is nothing new though so you can't be wrong with it once you decide to watch it or not. The biggest flaw for the show is the horrible pacing. Sometimes it feels rushed and other times it is stuck with filler episodes for characters nobody cares for. This would have worked better as a 12 episodes show I believe.\n\n
CHARACTERS\n
I will focus on the two main characters Misaki and Usui. Misaki is your typical "perfect girl" with obvious tsundere atributes. She is hard-working, intelligent and athletic, and she IS NOT in love with Usui. Usui is more of a Mary Sue than Misaki. He is handsome, clever, athletic and has that mysterious aura that makes him the most perfect guy in the whole school. Despite those characters being clichéd and lacking any significant personality, they are somewhat charming and interesting. They lack any kind of serious development or backstory making them just plot devices. You could replace them with any other character from any other show and you would get the same result. I have nothing to say about the support cast since every single one of the side characters is a bland archetype that is there for (a) fanservice or (b) get on Misaki's nerves.\n\n
CONCLUSION\n
Did I enjoy Maid-Sama? Yes, in a way it has its own charm. The comedy is funny enough and the dynamic between the main characters works well. On the other hand, it doesn't stand out in any way when compared to other anime of the same genre and therefore it is not more than just another average clichéd romcom.

Quite possibly the most pathetic anime I've had the misfortune to experience. The only reason I continued to watch the whole series was out of sheer disbelieve that it couldn't get any worse, yet every episode kept proving me wrong.
Story: 1
Your typical cookie-cutter anime overflowing with terribly overused cliches, except this particular show somehow is lazier than its thousands of look-a-like anime shows. There is NOTHING interesting going on: your typical anime rom-com featuring beautiful characters in a high school environment finding themselves involved in "wacky anime antics" with a minute or two at the very end of each episode of forced sentimentality to trickthe viewer into thinking that the show has a heart. Watching a brick tumble around in a washing machine is more emotionally investing than anything Maid-sama can hope to conjure up. A major proponent to this ugly story is the characters, which I will get into next.



Characters: 1


If you were to replace all the characters of the show with cardboard cutouts of retired NASCAR drivers, then nothing of value would be changed in the slightest. The characters in Maid-sama are easily some of the most dense, unmotivated, and inorganic I've ever witnessed in any anime. The female MC has a jaded view of all men, believing that they are all perverted scumbags, while the male MC, the run-of-the-mill cool guy who always has his hands in his pockets and his eyes half closed, is trying to convince her that guys are nothing to be scared of. Now, this might make for a good story, if it weren't for the fact that literally every guy in town IS a perverted scumbag. Every episode has a token scene of a group of guys sexually harassing a girl/girls at school, the female MC intervening, then the male MC making some unabashedly rude/insulting remark to irritate her, just generally being a terrible human being, yet because he's the MC, she always lets it slide, allowing him to abuse her emotions and sometimes her private space (in one episode he follows her into a back alley and directly pulls up her skirt to look at her panties. She calls him a "baka" and continues on normally). In one episode, the female MC is closing up shop alone at the maid cafe (her workplace), when she suddenly gets abducted, bound and gagged, and threatened at taser-point by two guys who give off some veeeeery unsettling sexual assault innuendos. She manages to break free and beat up her abducters, and walks away from the incident. The male MC, who was watching the scene unfold, tells her that she has to be more "tolerant" of men like them, or else people will start to hate her. AND THEN SHE BEGINS TO FALL IN LOVE WITH HIM. Because that's what real people do, right? These characters are totally believable, right?



Art/Sound: 1


Just as any canned anime, the art is unoriginal and the music is your typical rom-com soundtrack made to fill the episode with more noise, in addition to the mind-numbing voice acting. Nothing really else to say here, because there's nothing to look at or listen to.



Enjoyment: 1


No.



Conclusion:


The fact that so many people like this anime says a lot about the non-existent standards of the anime viewer base as well as the nosedive that the anime industry is taking right now. Cookie-cutter schlock that is shoveled out in droves every season in order to meet quota, yet since the frequent anime viewers' concept of what makes a good story is so saturated with the utterly lazy plot lines, the cardboard cutout characters shown in EVERY anime, and the complete absence of any real creativity leads them to believe that shows like Maid-sama are not complete audio/visual abominations.

I don't have the time to write a paper on this show but I'll write what I can.  Usually I procrastinate on doing this as I've noticed a lot of reviews are judged very harshly on MAL.  With that being said, I'll say that this show really surprised me to point that I feel compelled to write a review.  Now I'm a guy who enjoys anime but with a tad bit of romance thrown in.  Been watching that a lot lately and I was reading the recommendations of others for another show when I came upon this gem. The story wasgreat with good pacing; it didn't feel rushed but had a good gradual flow.  The art quality isn't that great compared to others but I have no complaints.  The sound was also okay, no songs that really stuck with me but the intro might be growing on me.  The characters were great also, no wimpy men here.  And I loved the heroine, strong yet insecure with an innocent charm.  Overall I really enjoyed watching this show; I realized I had a dumb smile on my face every episode.\n\n
Being a guy, I'm reluctant to head into the territory of shojou anime as it is for gggiiirrrlllsss.  But if more shojou are like this, then I'll definitely give them a try.  Sick of the wimpy men on the boys side anyway and I think a lot of guys would agree with me.  Now if you liked my review, please rate up.  If you didn't, kiss my...wait, that would be just gay.

MAID-SAMA! I'm a total fangirl and I love me some shoujo romance. Maid-sama is a cute anime with some interesting aspects and some formulaic stuff thrown in. 
First off, I enjoy the play of personalities with Misaki and Usui, they seem like total opposites but their personalities click, even if there's some denial on Misa's half. Usui comes off as an odd character to pinpoint at first. You don't really know what's going on in his head or how 'deep' the rivers of his personality really run. He'll surprise you with some of the things he does and his amount of insight into the worldaround him and into Misa. Misa herself isn't all that interesting. Basic plain-Jane, hard-working, man-hating (semi), overachieving character as many. She can come off a bit strong at first and maybe you won't like her all that much, but as the story progresses, you get to see her softer side and they interplay of her and Usui's personalities and you know that he's responsible for her growth in many ways so it makes you want to root for them as a couple even more. I love this kind of stuff, so for me this is fangirling heaven :D


Story: 7- Man-hating president goes undercover as maid, cute guy finds out, she has to keep it a secret. Lol. Yeah. Ok, not the best story ever, but it's cute! And it works!


Art: 6- Ahhh...the art... well, what can I say here? Sometimes it's awesome looking. At certain close-ups and during some scenes, it's down-right pretty (in a basic shoujo romance way) but then most of the time it gets ugly and is VERY inconsistent.


Sound: -- Must admit I haven't paid much attention to it. I will talk about the ED and the LOLness that ensued. It's just one of those WTF LMAO kind of things.


Character: so far...6-7- It's not that I don't enjoy Usui (because I do!) and it's not that I dislike Misaki (because I don't, I just hope she's not like Hikari from SA). I'm just waiting for some in-depth character development or some back-story or SOMETHING! 


Enjoyment: 8- Laugh out loudness in the form of shoujo goodness. I love it all. You might too.

Kaichou wa Maid-sama! is a masterpiece when it comes to shōjo anime. Being one of my personal favorites for years, I decided to re-watch it and to my surprise, I came to love it even more and bonded more strongly with the characters. What makes this a masterpiece? The two main protagonists. Ayazuwa Misaki is my role model. She is the perfect definition of feminism: strong, independent and hardworking. Her ideal goal is to to have more female students in a recently opted co-ed school Seika High so she's always fighting for equal rights. She's working extra hard to not only support her family butalso maintain her role as president of the student council to create a more fitting environment for girls in school, while working part-time at a maid cafe. It's always so refreshing to see a strong female lead on-screen and Misaki's character was the perfect touch. On the other hand, Usui is the perfect man any girl/guy could ask for. He’s smart, caring, incredibly sexy and always makes the best dirty jokes (!!). Did I mention that he's an amazing cook as well? He's perfection. Their relationship was key to success of the anime. Both the characters were mature so there weren't any unwanted whiny/dragged out scenes but instead we get to see a beautiful friendship bloom into love. The entire anime was a perfect combination of comedy, friendship and romance with wonderful characters. Definitely a masterpiece when it comes to shōjo anime.

Although this Anime would look to be the normal cliche type rom/com, it was actually pretty enjoyable Seika High School, once an all-boys school notorious for its wild students and for generally being a terrifying place for girls, has recently become a co-ed school, Misaki Ayuzawa the first female student council President of the school will do anything to reshape and allow the girls to be safe in a rough environment despite of her appearance she secretly works a part-time job at a maid cafe as a waitress maid in order to support her family needs. When Usui Takumi discovering her in maid uniform heis taking interest in her. Despite the series' fabulous artwork and a lot of great comedy, it is unfortunately a bit of a disappointment.

he premise behind Maid-sama has an initially interesting series.



Story 8/10

The beginning was really nice also the joy of viewers while watching it Although the base of the story does look to be some sort of cliche

the way they protect each other the romance slowly grows while they go through their daily problems at school and routines with a good amount of comedy it was actually pretty enjoyable with a few different aspects and information to it.

The sound was really clear and it really relates the mc is though, and the japanese voice acting matched the characters very well. The anime itself has correctly initiated sound effects that help bring the real feel of the moments depicted and  summarizes the whole anime quite well.

Overall 9/10

One of the best Romance and comedy that I watched I highly recommend this anime.If you disagree or want to discuss the topic further, comment on my profile or send me a pm :)

Class President is a Maid! Is a Romcom/Shoujo following Class President Misaki (yeah you guessed it, she is a maid), an admirer in Usui Takumi and a group of colourful characters such as "The Moron Trio". This series can be as light, or serious as you want to take it as it does follow some fairly complex and in depth themes, though there is certainly no problem just watching it for the plentiful humour around, and... the abundance of cross-dressing, if that's your thing!
The actual plot here is an interesting one and is what drew me in, essentially respectful tyrant in Class President Misaki isforced to play the role of a maid in a Maid Cafe because of her families situation, her biggest admirer and stalker in Usui finds out and blackmails her into a relationship... of sorts. It is carried out fairly well from the awkwardness of a girl with no time to love to an ending that almost gets there, we of course have many other characters with their role to play and fitting serious backgrounds to go with.


The art itself surely held up, as you can see the different emotional standpoints shine through at times and we have some lovely backgrounds to prove that. Fanservice is surely there as is expected from an anime surrounding a maid cafe, there is no ecchi relations in it though, its just there.


Character progression is a big one in this series, we see really a bunch of school kids working through their own problems and getting through life. The peak of one of these problems or even insecurities is of course the aim of this anime so the characters involved (and not) have a lot to play in this progression.


Overall it was just really enjoyable, as I said it can be taken as lightly as you want or you get get head over heals emotionally involved with this one (though I wouldn't suggest it because there is only the one season) exploring the eventual opening up of a girl that has lived a hard and independent life whose job is to stay as emotionally detached as possible. Have fun with this one guys, quite the roller coaster ride!

Not something unique ,but interesting. It shows that even though you are willing to do things on your own or you have a competitive nature there is only so much you can do.  
If I were to use a word to describe this anime then I would use simplicity. However it is the kind of simplicity that makes it enjoyable: a cool guy that is always calm looks after an energetic girl that gets her hands full at work and at school all because they are a perfect match. It may not bring something new but it's moments never cease to be amusing. Eventhough the outcome looks grim at certain times it will certainly cheer you up with some good lines that that trigger a change as soon as the songs pop up.\n
I've noticed artwork is somewhat sloppy at times but I believe the overall atmosphere makes it worthwhile watching since it always made me laugh.

Where do I begin. I was hesitant to watch this anime at first. I was actually rewatching OHHC when this anime was on the suggestions list on YouTube and I thought what the heck. 
I am so glad I did. 
Kaichou surpassed my expectations more than I could have ever imagined. I don't think that it is "typical" or "cliche" because there are many things that are unique to this anime. 
Story 9.5/10 
This is a rom com but the story and the set up where very entertaining. The plot is very maneuverable and flows with ease with lots of comedy and romance and feelsmoments all over. I would say that the manga has a smoother plot but thats because it took the story further than the anime did. \n\n
Art 9/10\n
At first I didn't like the art but I grew to love it. I guess what I didn't like the most was the hair and to be fair, I was judging this anime a lot based on OHSHC (I'm not sure why) and I liked the smoothness of Ouran's art versus Kaichou's but once I got passed that I could see that the art really is wonderful. (Usui is so gorgeous)\n\n
Sound 7/10\n
This was def. the weakest point for me. I love it when animes have beautiful music but I don't "discriminate" if they don't. However I wasn't really feeling Kaichou's. I liked the OP and I liked the first ending but thats kind of it. The effects throughout the anime where not appealing but they weren't annoying either. For me it just wasn't the strongest point. \n\n
Character 9/10\n
I'm giving this 9/10 bc of the supporting cast. They were developed okay. If it was just based on Usui and Mikasa it would be a 10 for me. Not that the suporting cast WASN'T developed its just that they weren't AS developed as the main leads and i think they could have done more with it. \n\n
Overall and Enjoyment 10/10\n
I finished this anime in 2 days. I was so hooked and I went immediately to finish it through the manga. It had me squeeling and I loved every second of it. I think that it's one of the best romance anime's that there are and if you haven't seen this anime yet and you are a fan of romance I recommend you do that ASAP.

Fortunately, you will be able to watch other romance animes besides that one. Really, it's almost a good thing to be able to fully appreciate the nothingness and the emptiness of these episodes sandwiched together and called, beyond my comprehension, an anime : because if you're being able to enjoy that one, then believe me, every other animes with similar theme will transport you WAY farther.
Along the lines, and with the very first episodes at that,you will first notice the total absence of a scenario. Kaichou wa Maid-sama is not a story, it's a setting. And that's it. It could have been not that badif this setting was explored at least thoroughly ... but forget it : with old jokes, inconsistent scenes, confusing dialogues, that was not going to happen.\n\n
With that, you could expect tremendous cute characters drawings and art, yes ? \n
Sorry, not happening either. The authors must have spend a far amount of time away, on a desert island, watching each other faces on a close-up and have selfishly decided it was good enough to put this exercise into an anime. Prepare yourself :\n
It's not that bad, but still your eyes could get hurted along the way.\n
...\n
Since I don't want to give up more time to this anime than I already have, I will wrap things here and now and tell you this :\n
If you are a veteran anime fan, or if you have already watched a few romance anime, stay far away from this one. It's not that the anime is actually so bad, and if i could describe it more accurately, I would dare to say it's kind of "pointless". You're going to end up, midway, totally indifferent to the setting, the characters, the story (ouch! the word hits me !) etc ...\n
If you're new to the romance anime theme, don't give up. Sure, this one lacks a bit of the warm, strong and lovely feelings you could find in others, but perhaps it's still watchable as it could satisfy you in its own pace...

Kaichou wa maid sama is a story featuring a young teenage girl misa chan who attends seika high school formally known as a all boys school turned co ed only recently. with misa's family financial situation thanks to her long lost father she must attend this school because of the low fee. Despite her hatred towards all male beings. She decided to make the most of her time here and become student council president to rule over the boys her top priority to have more girls enroll to even out the amount of students so girls can have there say. even with the authority andpower it cant hide the shame she would feel if one of the students at seika high caught her at her embarrassing part time job maid latte as you can tell from the tittle the role is to dress up as a maid waitress to serve customers and to make them feel at home in a warm environment. so imagine what she felt when she is caught by Usui.\n\n
Usui is also a student at seika high  AKA mister perfecto except his ways of making girls at seika high cry. scolded many times by the prez ( misa ) he finds out the truth about Misa's lifestyle and they become very close even when Misa refers to him as the perverted alien.  I love this anime because of the Misa the main chick if you love Tsundere girls as much as I do you will enjoy this anime there's a very small love triangle towards the end but only very small no tears will be shed children. Usui and Misa have a perfect example of a love/hate relationship except its only one sided though unfortunately you will have to suffer through the painful experience of Misa chan's denseness towards Usui's  feelings but I suppose that's what makes the drama if your a fan of shugo chara,kodocha,gakuen alice, or wolf girl & black prince then you will LOVE this anime!

This story is… interesting. I consider it very much like Chibi Vampire with how the characters act. We got our main character, Misaki Ayuzawa, who is a lot like Karin in how she sort of freaks out. She has a secret she doesn’t want anyone else to know about and jumps if even a mention of her secret might be leaked out, instead of Vampire it’s a maid. Then we have the love interest, Usui… OH COME ON! That’s the same name as in Chibi Vampire Karin! They could have at least made it a different name then something that is so similar. And evenhis personality is the same with his rather cold nature and quiet disposition. I think the only difference in the two characters is that Misaki is rather headstrong and rather harsh, not letting anyone help her but pushing them away thinking they are beneath her, and Usui is basically loved by every girl instead of feared by them. 


So I guess I should get into the characters more. Misaki is a really strong willed girl with a deep hated of men though would protect them if they were about to get hurt. And really why wouldn’t she? Her father left her family with a large amount of debt and ran off. Her stubborn nature is only shown when she is outside of her home. Inside, she is rather nice to her younger sister and mother who is rather sick. Why is it that the parents are always needing their kids to grow up so fast in these types of anime, its either they are gone, sick, or left the child all alone. Why can’t we just have a character who has both a mother and father, a loving family that cares for her? It just makes Japanese families look really messed up if this is always the case. (I know this is not reality but sometimes people get the strange idea that Anime reflects exactly what is going on in Japan.) I would consider Misaki a ‘Hot then Cold’ type of girl, the tsundara type. She also is very head strong and will try and deal with things on her own instead of asking for help, pushing people away. I think its one of the reasons why she pushes Usui away so much. By the way, get used to her yelling ‘Stupid Usui’ a lot. 


As the show goes on, you see her growing and learning how to actually deal with them through Usui. Now, going with Usui, I consider him slightly like a stacker and slightly like a typical boy who just loves to tease a girl he has a crush on. I would love a guy like him king of since he pretty much seems dedicated to Misaki in almost every way, even when she is mean to him. So many girls keep asking him to go out with them but he always tells them no just so that he can be with her. He cares for her so much that he just seems to do anything he can think of to protect her, even if she can protect herself most of the time. There were a lot of times I thought that things were going to happen a certain way and ended up being different. On the other hand, I would hate it if the guy who was interested in me seemed to have no real personality in his voice for the most part and will show his personality through his actions alone. It would annoy me like it does for Misaki.


The other characters really just seem to end up being background characters, not really sticking out all that much. We have normal personalities like the cute one, the ditsy one, the normal perverted boys, and so on. They don’t really stand out except maybe the first three boys we see Misaki yells at. They are the ‘comedy trio’ like this show needs any more comedy. The background Misaki fan group. 


One of the most annoying episodes for me I would like to point out was episode 6. I was really annoyed with the Inuyama quintuplet brothers. It just really annoyed me having 5 of the same character talking at the exact same time. It just bothered me even if there was a lot of other things I liked as well Saying anymore though would spoil it so sorry, you just got to watch it yourself and suffer the quintuplets. Just trust me that you don’t want to skip that episode if you watch it.


I really am not sure what to think of this show. I keep finding all these things that make it just like another anime, but yet there are some things that make it a bit different. I guess when you watch a lot of anime like I do, you tend to run into a lot that feel like they are ripping off other anime stories, especially in a slice of life romance like this one. 


The art style is pretty basic for a romance slice of life. The artwork is colorful, the characters pretty looking in a shojo syle. There are random times when comedy is supposed to be pushed that the artwork seems to faultier but nothing really bad. It’s just really standard. Get used to a lot of flowers, sparkles, and colorful backgrounds that sometimes only have a pattern to them instead of actually being a normal area. What I like is that the maid outfit is not like a normal maid’s outfit. It looks pretty cool looking. There is one thing I don’t get though, a strange ‘ghost’ that keeps showing up every once in a while. It’s awkward and makes no sense since this is a romantic comedy and not an occult horror. The ghost is really cute looking but I can’t figure out why its there.


This is going to be a little hard for me to review as there are two different dubs to this anime. There is from Animax and then from Sentai. I tried a couple minutes of both to see what version I was going to review, and strangely, I liked Sentai version of Misaki Ayuzawa better then the Animax voice. It just feels like it has a lot more control and isn’t so high pitched that it would bother me when she yells. The Sentai also seemed to be closer to the Japanese sub although it also seems a bit gimmikie. For most of this review, I will be talking about Sentai because it’s really hard for me to watch two different dubs. I just picked the one I liked better. Not all that much better, but slightly better. It still suffers from high voices that sometimes sqweek and slightly off voices. When talking about Usui’s voice, he just doesn’t normally have a personality in his voice. He just seems super bored even when he raises his voice a bit. I can understand the fact that they were trying to make him sound all cool but it just makes me want him to give more personality. I do have to say that his voice is perfect for the romantic parts when he is serious but his joking voice makes me wonder if he really is just teasing her. It’s hard to tell. Now I’m not saying he doesn’t have a personality in his voice, he sometimes does but like I said before, his personality is in his actions.


I did like the show, but it was pretty standard. The story just felt like it was pretty much every other romance slice of life and didn’t bring anything really new to the table. If you seen one, you kind of seen them all. They also didn’t end it with an actual ending. They cleared some things up but left a lot of questions that never got answered. It’s pretty much a read the manga ending.

I love this anime! Granted, it doesn't have the best plot but if you're a sucker for cheesy romance then this is the right anime for you. I'm really picky about art, since I love more modern types like this one where the characters are cute but also look like teenagers instead of elementary geniuses that have found their way into high school. Usui is so cute and makes a cute couple with Misaki. I had so much fun watching their endlessly humorous arguments and cute moments. It was one fo my first animes and I would definitely recommend it to any girl  (orguy, I don't judge) that loves romantic comedy and a relatioship between a popular guy and  a not-so-popular-but-completely-badass-in-this-anime girl.

While I'm not finished with the series I felt I needed to write something about this anime. It's not your typical romcom by any measure. The romance seems intense at times and the comedy comes in quick to relieve the supposed tension from the encounters but it does so in the greatest way possible. And on the the breakdown thus far:
Story 10/10: This isn't your typical romcom and it doesn't set out to be compared to others like Clannad and Toradora. It may seem more light hearted when compared to those but the subtle inferences that occur get you hooked a few episodes in ifyou like this type of series. Just as the synopsis says it's about a girl who became student president in a largely male dominated school who is pretty protective of the other females in the school and of course a stickler for the rules. The story is largely based off her interaction with the male lead, Usiu, who is known around the school as a heartbreaker since so many girls are interested and he has never found one to feel like that about until he met Mirasaka. He becomes interested in her work and her drive to be the best she can be and he tries to protect and get closer to her whenever he can despite his in-sociable demeanor.


Art 7/10: The backgrounds definitely could be improved but the character drawing is pretty outstanding.


Sound (9/10): The opening and ending themes leave some sort of mystery to the series and the lives or Mira and Usiu. There haven't been many moments where in-episode music appeared but its been pretty good so far in accompanying the moments.


Character 10/10: Each of the leads and the supporting cast all have some pretty unique personalities when it comes to this genre and they can easily captivate you. A major reason I can keep watching after I watched 3 or so episodes they got me hooked.


Enjoyment 9/10: As i said the characters are unique and the story is pretty original while still working the comedic points into the overall plot. First time in a long time I actually laughed while watching this type of anime.


Overall 9/10


I would highly recommend watching this anime to anyone. the only reason it doesn't get a 10 is because of the background art but if you do not care for that then this is definitely a series you should pick up if at all interested in the romcom genre.

Story:
The story and plot was non existent, even what was there was just a huge cliche. Man hating, sexist female tsundere lead. Quiet guy that everyone likes. Who does he go for? Obviously the most annoying anime character ever made. Misaki or whatever.
art and sound
Art was actually decent, but just sparkle, sparkle everywhere. I don't think much about th sound... I guess it's okay...
Characters:
Misaki-worst character ever. Why does eveyone in the series like her? It's irritating she's annoying and doesn't know her own feelings. She tries to be a good person, but she just ends up being annoying. I hate how she's so kind andcaring, and then completely rude and irritating.\n\n

Only thing I can say is,if you're a big fan of rom/com anime,this anime is also suited for you.Being a big fan of the genre,its without reason that I should definitely see this one.Actually if you're a big fan of the genre its worth the time watching.The artwork is amazing for my perspective,the sound is quite authentic to the scene and always the right theme of the background music to a specific scene.Characters on the other hand do make up a great combination of Romance,Comedy and drama(shown by some characters like Usui and Misaki throughout the whole season).The character development was also great and howthey established a good change in the story.


Overall,I say its an anime where you can really enjoy watching.Tons of laughter,drama and romance.Although I somewhat feel like there should be a season 2 but I get the fact the main story is at an end for now.


Again totally recommended to watch even as a start to the genre of rom/com. 


THANKS FOR READING :D

This is one of the most frustrating animes of all time, for all the right reasons. With intriguing characters, interesting plot, and a kick-ass female lead, this anime will leave you a memorable impression and will have you scurrying to go read the manga. Remeber to check the overviews for the gist! 
        Story: 9.59/10 *Review Begins
Once an all boys school, Seika High, a re-owned school with reckless and filthy boys, now has turned into a co-ed. With the female population still being the minority, Misaki Ayuzawa decides to take it in her own hands to make theschool better for the girls. Studying, training, and being the first female student council president, Misaki gained the reputation of being a "demon that hates boys". As she works in a maid cafe to support her poor family, a popular boy Takumi Usui discovers her embarrassing secret. *This plot is intriguing, and it applies to many girls trying to prove themselves this day and age. While some parts may be sexist (Misaki working in a maid cafe), it doesn't really focus on her cosplaying at all. Rather it foucu's on her friendships and breaking down the barrier to let people in, and having a normal teenage life when she has to support her poor family. If that isn't inspirational, I don't know what is!


Over View: 

+ Plot is original

+ Plot is relatable

- Some parts are cliche (sexist)


       Art: 10/10

The art is eye-catching, and has a unique choice of colors to design the characters. Misaki isn't your typical big busted girl you see in almost every anime, but rather the kick-ass chick that can clearly pull her own wieght (and even others in some cases). The side-characters are animated in an intriguing way, and the male lead is attractive too (but not overly attractive in a cliche way).


Overview:

+ Characters animated well

+ Characters aren't overly attractive 

+ Unique color pallet


       Sound: 9.97/10

The voice acting (in subbed) is attractive, pleasing to the ear, and very fluent. The voice fit the personalities of the characters (this is a MUST to me), especially Misaki's. Misaki's voice is unique and fits her character very well, it's not the annoying chimpmuck voice, but rather a soothing voice on the deeper end. This suites her personally perfectly. Usui's voice is attractive and pleasing. The opening theme song "Keep My Secret" is perfect for the anime, but not as catchy as I would've hoped. The scheme in the begginig in fantastic, and I watch it every episode (even when my iPad is 6 percent). 


Overview:

+ Voice acting done well

+ Ending is catchy

-Oening doesn't entirely fit the anime


          Character: 9.96/10

Misaki was a refreshing badass female lead (FINALLY) and is one of my favorites. She has flaws, such as Hero Syndrome (always having to save the day), and this is my faveroite aspect of her. This is found in far too many male leads *cough* SAO *cough*, and having it in a female and having it done well was a punch in the gut! I was surprised that they didn't make her the "innocent big-eyed beauty" for a plot being surrounded around a Maid Cafe. She also trains, studies, and is the Student Prez. Finally a female lead that doesnt follow her man around like a puppy! Usui was funny and wasn't an asshole all the time, and wanted to protect her, but he knew she can pull her own weight too. He is handsome, and is a great character while not being the 'perfect' man to set foot on Earth. The side characters were amazing, but didn't go into much depth as I hoped ( i.e Yukirmara). Misaki was a tad bit to ignorant about Usui's love though, I wish the animators had made her realize it sooner.


Overview:

+ Personalities weren't cliche 

+ Animated well

+ Miskaki didn't follow around Usui like a lost puppy

- Miskaki was too ignorant about Usui's crush.

- Side characters didn't go in depth.


       Enjoyment: 10

I enjoyed this series down to the very last episode (though I was mad when it ended), and it left me scrambling to go to the nearest manga store to pick up the newest volume. The characters were intriguing, plot original, and a female lead I liked. It tooke me about 1 day and and to finish (marathon), and I hope you plan to watch this anime too!


Over View

+ Great characters

+ Interesting plot

+ Kick-ass female lead (I know I keep saying this, but it's true!)


       Overall: 9.89/10

Overall I give this a high nine, and many of the fact were small details that caused this to be a tad bit to cliche (Miaski was wayyyyy to ignorant). I loved the characters (Yukirmara is my absolute favorite!) and I really liked the entire setup.


Key: 

*= start of story review

+ = good things

- = bad things

Though the anime is not so funny but mixing a funny element and a great plot is making this anime good.

Perhaps i am over stepping my mark by rating a Shoujo which is inherently aimed towards girls, as a guy. But given the MC's reputation as a tsundere, a popular character trait amongst male anime audiences, i feel a certain obligation to report on the content of the show for those looking to consume that kind of content.
The art is pretty average, though I was impressed by how seamless some of the transitions were between the general scenes and obviously budget panoramic backgrounds. The sudden switch in quality somehow isn't noticeable enough to draw from the overall feel of the show the rest of theart provides. The sound usually isn't worth mentioning unless it's bad, but it's pretty important for comedic timing and the show doesn't stumble there which is worth acknowledging on some level.


My main problem though is with the story, since there doesn't appear to be one. It starts off about  the male lead who discovers the female lead's secret, embarrassing job; and the need to maintain that secret during her school tenure for reputations sake as the [insert god-like female school president] trope. But after the first 8 or so episodes this somewhat gets forgotten about along with the primary antagonist who implies a revenge that never comes (if only indirectly through and at the convince of a peer of theirs). Nothing of note really happens from here all the way until episode 21 when we finally see some actual character development.


For about a dozen episodes through all the series' teens the show gets stuck on "tease" mode and seriously over stimulates the subtlety of romantic tension where half way through it all becomes a giant chore to sit through. Do they spend any quality time together? Do they have any moments of accidental closeness? At the risk of creating a spoiler, no. There is that gem at the end of episode 21, before stalling and climaxing in the final 2 episodes, 25 and '6.


So what can we really say about the characters? Well the archetypal tsundere is actually a character development process that improves over time in positive respects. It could be argued that some progression occurs for the female lead as Misaki becomes more susceptible to the teasing of Usui, but the consequences of which just amount to "more frequent and intense blushing" and no actual changes of circumstance; but for the late introduction of a childhood friend and eventual love rival (that causes Usui to exhibit his first human emotion, jealousy), which just like the initial plot and antagonist, also gets lost and forgotten about.


You can tell the show is a Shoujo though since the female MC is the only character with any kind of embellishment; hell even the male lead, Usui has zero character background other than the fact he lives alone in a somewhat expensive apartment. This really makes it difficult to relate to him on top of the fact he's a border line Mary Sue. So perfect that his only flaw is his own perfection. Excellent at studies, excellent at sports, near super human resistance to pain and injury and so charming it'd make the average person puke. He's a text book Disney Prince which actually makes for incredibly boring watching, except presumably for fantasising girls. As for everyone else, they pretty much only exist, but for one random tangent about the local delinquents, solely to drive the plot. Which isn't at all refreshing.


I would like to go into more depth and clarity, but i also want to keep this concise enough that people will actually read it. This show missed a lot of opportunities in my opinion, but such is the nature of foregoing a full story for fan service. I don't think i'd recommend this unless you genuinely had a maid fetish that needed addressing. I don't even think the tsundere is even all that tsundere since she wears the cape of tsun' right up until the closing episode. Which just makes her frustrating to watch more than "endearing".

Well I came to see a romance I heard was popular online. While I guess I enjoyed myself, there are a lot more romances that outshine Kiachou wa Maid-sama! I feel that it defines average for the romance genre.
Story: 5/10
There wasn't really all that much guiding the story besides the fact Takumi likes Misaki. Sure there were interesting short arcs, but no overarching plot-line to push the story forward. Very much slice-of-life, but with no real direction. Lots of cliche episodes like the beach episode. Nothing I particularly disliked, but nothing to keep me interested either. I guess I kind of enjoyed certain plot elementslike the set up of a female lead in a authority position over a bunch of hoodlum guys, but I'm not really sure much propelled me to finish the show other than I was curious if the two mains got together. There was no drive for me to see them together. The very last story arc introduced a new character as well and sort of threw off the whole vibe of the show. Not the best story planning I've seen.


Art: 6/10


Fine. I may not have seen it in the best quality, but it seemed pretty generic for the romance genre.


Sound: 3/10


Poor. Like really. I could not find anything that sounded good at all. The sub was so high pitched that I hated it, and the dub was pretty high and seemed off. Maybe it was the quality of the particular video I was watching. I don't think so.


Character: 3/10


This is where I probably have the most to say. Firstly: I freakin' loved Misaki. She was totally awesome and really fit the strong female lead role. Her responses and actions fit her and seemed real. Loved a scene where she was accidentally drunk. It was hilarious. On the other hand, I positively HATED Takumi. Seriously? This is what the author thought a princely-type guy should be like? I went through the show thinking he would change, but no. This was just what the author thought would be attractive. Yeah, no. Go look at Ouran High School Host Club for a good princely lead. Not a freakin' stalker. Lastly, a somewhat major character was introduced in the last few episodes, and really threw off the show. Instead of focusing on deepening the shallow relationship, they just tried to drive a wedge in between and after the two overcoming it, said "Ohh I guess we were in love...." Stupid. This category really depends on your like of Takumi.


Enjoyment: 7/10


That all said, it was hard to really not enjoy the show somewhat. Not at all stressful to watch and had a pleasant, if odd, ending. I might just be easy to please. I don't really recommend this show unless you've finished the countless others that are better, but I guess it's not bad. It might be better if you like Takumi more.


Overall: 5/10

Story: kaicho wa maid-Sama is my favorite romance anime of all time. Mostly because of the story plot line. The story is really compelling and it does and amazing job of drawing its audience in. It's story is very unique which makes it 10 times more interesting to watch.
Art: the art in the anime is well done I particularily like the type of style they used when drawing the characters because it really matches the characters personality really well.
sound: the sound was alright but It never really stood out much, it was always in the background to the point where I ended up not listeningto it, the voice acting was fine it was mostly the music I didn't like.


Characters: the characters were really well thought out. They all were different and very interesting, I wanted to find out more about each and every character. Sometimes the choices some of them make I couldn't really agree with but it ended up making the plot continue so i could bare with it.


Enjoyment: I think everyone who loves romance anime will absolutely love this anime, I enjoyed almost everything in it and have watched it over and over again. If you watch this I promise it will be a anime you won't ever forget.


Overall: I give this anime a 10 because there are so many good points about it that the bad parts seem so small that they don't really matter. Of coarse it's different with all animes but particularily this one is very enjoyable I recommend this anime to anyone who is either looking for really good romance anime to watch or is just starting watching anime.

This is a very good show. It is humorous, interesting and best of all, the character development. Once you started watching, you will be attracted to the story progress. This show is Recommended for All.

"Sometimes the things that you don't want people to see in life make you stonger, smarter, and sometimes can make you fall in absolute love."
One day, I was looking for a good romance. Classy, sweet, funny, and hot all at the same time. Where would I find such a ridiculous anime like that? That could give me all of those features and I would find it memorable? Maid-sama has certainly pulled it off.
How many of you can say you hate that one guy in the class just because he annoys you, he's almost close to perfect, and he's popular? Those type of people are soannoying because they always seem to get the best of you. Why? Because you never measure up to him and certainly not date them. But those are the type of situations that strike up the most wild roller coaster relationships that will make the viewer laugh, smile, frown, and fell remorse all at the same time.


The story is a little of a cliche taking a girl who is so headstrong, independent, and smart into a high school of mostly boys. She can't officially get a boyfriend because all of the boys are mentally scared of her. Now, here comes the (DING) perfect, hot, sexy boy who secretly falls for her. And in almost every episode you can find them fighting or battling over some sort of thing that brings them closer every time. It was kind of unoriginal but this is one heck of a joyride! I loved almost every second of it and not once did I yawn, which I do in most serious romances. This is truly funny! (& I'm not one to laugh out loud at much Anime)


The art was fantastic, it's not out of this world great but the design of everyone was great. The sound was kind of a blah, especially the opening buy hey we can't always get everything under the tree! The characters are average but for the girls Usui is very attractive that you will find yourself drooling for the dang guy!


The enjoyment was great, just pure awesome. It gave everything I wanted to see in a romance. Because real life romance do have funny, love and hate relationships and whether we like it or not, there will be someone you can't absolutely stand but at the end of the day you'll find yourself saying "Hey, he really isn't that bad".


(Note: For those of you who think this is like Kimi ni Todoke... I warn you IT IS NOT for various reasons. One it's a comedy and two the girl isn't shy!)


Thank you for reading! :)

I’ve been trying to watch Kaichou wa Maid-Sama! (I’ll just call it Maid-Sama from now on) for a while now, but due to one of the worst dubs I’ve ever heard in my life, I gave up on it (I don’t really like to watch romance anime in Japanese and I almost always prefer dub to sub for any show). So, when they finally did a redub (ty Sentai) I was pretty excited. Anyway, back to the series at hand: this show is by J.C. staff and, as hinted about before, is a romance (a Shoujo romance, to be specific). I’ll let you read thesynopsis on your own if you so wish because this is all I really have to say in the preamble. 

Let’s get the aesthetics out of the way first:



Art and Animation: 

I can start right off the bat by saying that I really liked the art style of this show. It was a really wholesome and fun art style and really fit the show well. Character design was also a real strong point as well; Misaki’s character design was especially great and all female cast members were unique looking. As for the males, it seems like all of the males who were trying to “get” Misaki had blonde/light hair for some reason. This was really weird to me since most Japanese men have black hair. Another thing the show does well in the art department is the use of Chibi. I for one, usually think Chibi is overdone and annoying but, this show pulled it off really well by using it mostly on the “3 idiot” male characters (it was quite funny every time you would see them in Chibi). The colours of the show were great as well, they were very glitzy and sparkly especially when it came to deeper moments between Usui and Misaki; this show was not afraid to showcase its bright colours. The animation was fine as well, there’s not much going on movement wise in shows like these, but when there was a lot of movement, it was solid. Also, I’d like to mention that when something dramatic would happen (Usui “shockingly” saves Misaki) the show would do this slow-mo dramatization thing which I found pretty hilarious because of how corny it was. 



Sound: 

I’ll be honest, the shows soundtrack was not my cup of tea. I always skipped the opening after listening to it once and I didn’t even bother with the ED. As for the OST, there’s usually like 3 main tracks they go to. The very happy and “cute” song they use when everything is fine and normal, the very sad sounding one for when someone is having a flashback or something – I really hate this one, it always sounded so damn creepy to me, and the excited and glamorous track for when something totally “ZANY!!!” is happening. Overall, it’s okay, but just not my taste. Voice actors were solid as well, I thought Misaki’s VA matched her personality very well.



Characters: 

Maid-Sama features a wide array of characters, but the majority of the focus is put towards our main couple (obviously), Usui and Misaki. I will comment on the supporting cast all at once first though. Essentially, the show mostly uses its background support cast for comedic relief. There are times however where the story revolves around one of the side characters. The most notable comic relief characters are the “3 idiots” as Misaki refers to them in the show. They are easily my favourite characters from the whole show due to their idiotic (yet funny) charm. The rest of the cast usually has one trope attributed to them that defines them really (not much depth for many of them). There’s the 3 idiots as mentioned before, the other employees at the Maid Café, the Vice President from the student council and his sidekick Kanou (I also like him for being pretty much the only sane character towards the end), Aoi (obligatory trap), and the main rival against Usui for Misaki’s love, Hinata. Now, I’m not going to go through each and every one of them so I will say that the most notable ones here are Hinata, Aoi, and Kanou. These side characters don’t really matter much in the long run though since this is a romance between (mostly) two individuals: Misaki and Usui. Starting off with Misaki, I can say she is a very likeable and strong female lead. She doesn’t like to play the damsel and she actually has a personality to her. Sadly, this is ruined about her as the series progresses on as she keeps getting “saved” by Usui. It really gets tiresome and repetitive when you keep seeing that she can’t do things she heavily resolves to accomplish alone (which is the main point and drive of her character) and then this perfect alpha male saves her. Speaking of Usui, well, plain and simple he’s pretty much a douchebag. He is “perfect” in everything he does and has no personality or backstory at all (no backstory yet, until the girl figures it out like many other shoujo). His only goal in life (as far as we see and know) is to get with Misaki, but he’s such a little twat about it that it’s unbearable to watch sometimes. Other than that, we know nothing about him at all and it really isn’t the sign of a good character to be perfect at everything he does. This makes Usui very very irritating towards the end of the series. I didn’t mind him at first (I actually kind of liked him), but as the series progressed, especially when Hinata was introduced, it seemed more and more clear to me that he was just an arrogant, hollow, maniac for the fan girls to fall in love over. 



Story:

The story is about a hardworking girl who is the strict student council president of her high school while also working as a maid at a café (to her embarrassment) and how she falls in love with a guy who figures out her secret. The antics mostly revolve around her trying to cover up her secret of being a maid from everyone she knows from her high school. As with any romance, the show heavily relies upon the dynamic between the two main leads. This dynamic is the driving point of the story and is what keeps you invested to keep watching. There are story arcs within the show that focus on different side characters but, usually it comes down to our main heroine who has to make a choice or take on a task and our male lead will always help her on the way whether she likes it or not. Essentially, this show is a romance with a tsundere through the eyes of the tsundere. As I mentioned before, the show relies heavily upon the chemistry and bond between the two leads. In the beginning, the couple seems very natural and likeable, but later on things turn for the worse as Usui’s major flaw of being flawless becomes apparent. Essentially so, if they spent more time developing Usui as much as they tried to develop Misaki i.e. give Usui an actual personality, not make him a knight in shining armour deus ex-machina, then the show’s romance aspect would have flowed much better. The romance between the two becomes really irritating and rushed towards the end when the love triangle between Hinata, Usui, and Misaki is formed. Usui shows his truly irritating possessive side and Hinata is thrown away like trash, making you dislike both main characters even more. On top of this, it doesn’t help that they rush Usui and Misaki’s romantic development greatly in one episode. They do the same thing as they’ve always done in this last episode but, instead, *SPOILERS* Misaki finally draws this conclusion that she loves Usui. This doesn’t really make any sense, comes out of nowhere and had very little foreshadowing, seeing the fact that she was acting pretty much the same before this towards him as she was throughout the whole story.



Overall: 

Despite the gripes with it, I’d say Maid-Sama is, overall, actually a really enjoyable show for the most part. It becomes a little unbearable to watch and cringy for me after episode 20. Though enjoyable, it is flawed, character-wise and plot-wise (the romance). The show was very funny at times, so in a sense it did serve its purpose there. But, if you’re going to have serious moments in a comedy-romance (you usually do) you have to make sure they are executed well. A lot of this shows dramatic faults came from Usui and how unrealistic he could be. The dynamic between the two main leads fell apart as the show went on and you were left with a hollow slice of life with a rushed ending and no feeling of satisfaction. I’m pretty sure the ending was Manga-bait so don’t spaz out for me for my thoughts here. Also, I know some of you fangirls/boys will think I hate this show, but I don’t, I just think they could’ve done better. Please don’t get your panties in a twist; if there is a sequel and Usui gets some development and overall, the show improves, I will give it a higher score (lol definitely won’t catch me reading the manga, sorry). As for now though, this show is a 'meh' for me. 


Final Score: 5/10
