Kaichou wa Maid-sama... Where do i start? 
Be cautious, I tried not to say any spoilers, but if you are very sensitive about any sort of spoilers, you might not want to read. (Only 'Spoilers' contained includes vaguely explain the concepts and story of certain episodes, it's not enough to spoil the whole plot or anything of similar caliber).
Story 1/10:
This anime didn't seem to carry much of an overall story. It reminded me highly of many American cartoons, in the sense of a new event happening every episode, with many fillers. I felt like there was no clear objective that the writers were going for.They kept compiling events were it seemed like Ayuzawa needed help, and Usui either came to the rescue, or if Ayuzawa was able to get out of the situation herself, he would talk to her about what just happened. I admit that I'm a sucker for anime romance, but I felt like it dragged out. I did not think that this show needed 26 episodes, they could have easily wrapped up the story within 12 or 13 episodes.


Art 6/10:


The art in this anime wasn't particularly bad, I just felt like there is a lot of room for improvement. I personally felt like during the kissing scenes, the mouths looked strangely smaller than what i'm used to, but i'm not completely sure about that one. Besides that, they seemed to use chibi like designs and"gray blobs" more often than not. I also found that the backgrounds seemed very repetitive, especially the episode where Ayuzawa and her friends followed Usui around. A lot of the streets, houses, shops, and such were very similar in design. Lastly they seemed to rely on closeup shots for a large portion of each episode.


Sound 5/10:


The voice acting (besides the small portion of English voice acting), is pretty solid. Regardless there are always going to be that one voice that you hate, and this anime definitely had some. Overall, they seemed to rely on their theme music (which i personally find catchy, but almost overused) and sound effects to create the drama points. This is a trick that many anime use. Furthermore it is something that should accompany more appropriate scenes to either pump up viewers for an upcoming fight, or even shock viewers with silence during a dramatic scene. This anime didn't seem to connect the story and the sound as nicely as other series.


Characters 2/10:

The characters in this series were extremely recycled. Many of the male characters were shown as disgusting, unorganized, porn-loving, perverts. In a lot of other series you will come across the pervert characters, but this series was practically all about the fact that every guy wants to abuse girls (sexual harassment is shown often, but not followed through in this anime) including every single guy at the school, except for the innocent Yukimura. Besides similar personalities, many characters have similar appearances as well. There are multiple guys that look the Usui, two characters that look like Yukimura, many of the background charaters looked very similar and generic, many of the girls all had similar short hair cuts (including background characters). I felt like this series didn't have much development or creativity when it came to creating characters.


Enjoyment 1/10:


I did not enjoy this series at all. It did not feel like an anime, it felt like a cartoon. There wasn't anything to attach me to the show after I watched the first couple of episodes. Once the characters and their environment was set up, it really didn't grab my attention any longer. I felt like watching the show was very boring and I don't even know if i'll be continuing the series after watching half of the show.


Overall 3/10:


The anime did have fair art, but the lack of story, character, and sound creativity, off balances that. I didn't enjoy watching this anime because it slowly turned cliche. However I admit that the whole concept of the show (as in a 'good girl' working at a maid/cosplay restaurant) is capturing. I just didn't think they did the best job writing a story to go alone with the subject. However I can understand why many people would love a series if they are interested in romance/slice of life series, you might find this one has a flavor of originality. I am only giving this anime a poor score because I don't enjoy anime that are all about goofing off, without any real form of a serious side.

Overall, I really love Maid Sama. It's adorably romantic. However, I do believe the series dragged on quite a bit, and this is why it's given a 9/10. Let me explain.
Through the first 8ish episodes, I was extremely hooked. I thought Usui's attempt at Ayuzawa was extremely adorable. This drive, really kept me in the series for future series.
 However, I believe in many later episodes; they hardly focus on the original plot itself. She's a maid and student body president, and she doesn't want anyone to know, correct? I felt as if it swayed (many times) away from that original idea of having hersecret kept. I mean, in many terms I get it. The writers cannot keep going back to that always, but I believe it should've had something to contribute to it most of the time; and those later episodes hardly did for me. \n
Usui and Ayuzawa's ongoing romance (before becoming a couple) was also really dragged out, longer than it needed to be. \n\n
However, overall the series was incredible adorable. It did make me laugh, extremely, and the ending was not near disappointing. It's a heart-warmer.

When I was a young lass I adored shoujo, and I adored this anime. But the problem is, it's aged terribly. I suppose those new to the anime scene could find a basic enjoyment of it, but I personally found myself quite uncomfortable re-watching. It, like many romance animes of the time, relies on tropes. Don't get me wrong, tropes can work, that's why they're there. Unfortunately they were more popular when Kaichou was released than now.
So why did I feel uncomfortable watching a silly romance? Well, here's the tea, sis. All the male characters (except the cross dressing boy, I don't remember his name-I only remember he was quite obnoxious) have very rape-y tendencies. That includes the comic relief, 90% of the re-occurring villains, and the main love interest, Usui. He's a stalker, harasser and overall creep. Tbh, I've met real-life Usui's before and I've had to call the cops on them.\n
Don't think this shields the main character from critique, the titular maid. She is an example of another, thankfully, dead trope. The strong independent Tsundere. Except she's just as bad as the guy who likes her; she's abusive to all men, so she'd probably get a job at Buzzfeed. Aw, but she's poor so she has to do her best. Except she has an unrelentingly violent personality and her 'independence' never gets endearing, rather you find yourself progressively angrier at her.\n
I don't want to be that nasty person who says don't watch this. Some people will enjoy it. But if you enjoy well built romances between well rounded characetrs that actually have personality then this isn't for you. I wanted to enjoy watching you Kaichou, you were my childhood. But I suppose I've outgrown you and it's time to put you in the trash.\n

Story [4]
One of the main flaws of this particular show is the way that it relies on archetypes and cliches to tell it's story. Kaichou wa Maid-sama is the genericl romcom in which the richest/hottest/most popular guy in the highschool falls in love with the protagonist for no real reason. The story still manages to score a 4 simply because it is a relatively interesting rendition of mediocre shoujo stereotypes.
Art & Sound [5]
There isn't much to say when it comes to the art in Kaichou wa Maid-sama, and likewise for the audio. They are about what is expected, and they don't have any glaring flaws,but nothing more.


Character [3]

The worst part of Kaichou wa Maid-sama are the characters. They are flat, have no real character arcs, and are stereotypical. That being said, the main girl is not absolutely terrible and has a few character traits of her own. Although Misaki Ayuzawa has been written off as a tsundere (and this isn't false, per se) there is reasoning behind it. Unlike many other shoujo heroines, Misaki is a feminist and has something of a hatred for men. The latter trait isn't positive, but that's exactly what makes it meaningful and lets Misaki stand out, even a little, amongst an ocean of bad main characters.


Still, this series gets a 3 in character because aside from Misaki, everyone is reeaaally flat. Misaki herself isn't anywhere near being impressive enough to salvage that train wreck. :/


Enjoyment [10]

There is a reason that this anime has managed to be as popular as it is- and I'll give you a hint, it isn't just by riding on hype or the coattails of another anime. Kaichou wa Maid-Sama can't stand up against any sort of formal review or critique, but it's well loved simply because it is enjoyable (as long as you haven't declared war against all shoujo tropes, that is).


Overall [9]

Despite the bad scores in almost every department, I gave Kaichou wa Maid-Sama a overall score of 9 simply because it achieves it's goal. It's not trying to be unique- it's just a cliche romance anime with a cliche plot and a cliche cast of characters. What makes this anime notable is that it uses the cliches to their utmost extent. Kaichou wa Maid-Sama is the picture perfect shoujo, and for those who love that sort of thing, this anime is a must watch. For others, not so much.

I personally liked KWMS very much because of the qualities the main character, Misaki, has. She is a very independent, smart, and headstrong girl, who does what she can to help everyone. I think she makes for a very relatable character or at least a good role model. This anime is a romantic anime, but I find it very refreshing as the story revolves around a girl who knows what she wants to do and why; she is a girl who does not depend on people much, but she is also not without fault. Her nemesis is a good-looking boy who is too cool forwords and seems to enjoy teasing her. The outcome is inevitable.\n
The story has comedy and romance (of course) showing how Takumi has taken a liking to Misaki. But Misaki doesn't like him, she actually hates him. But the story develops where in Misaki, bit by bit, falls in love with him. Along the way, the series show how the characters develop as well, and the story has an abundant set of characters. All of them are used until the end of the series, so the story actually has consistency. The story also tackles about future goals in the later part of the series. The animation is quite normal actually. Nothing too bad, nothing too good as well, average. But it properly depicts the story from the manga series.\n
So it's actually a really good series all in all, gives you that wonderful essence of romance, along with humorous comedy beside it. And the story is consistent, and it shows the character's development.\n
I recommend this to all ages. The series is rather easy to follow and understand, so if you are a first time Anime watcher, then I recommend something like this. It's not too complicated, it's not too fancy, but it still has that uniqueness to its story. And it has a romantic-comedy nature so it is very easy to follow.I don`t want to say anything to spoil the show, but in my opinion it is a refreshing change from all the fantastical anime out there because of its realistic setting and characters.

Kaichou was Maid-Sama is one of those animes that you watch for fun, which it is fun and it is thoroughly entertaining for anyone who knows not to think too hard on it or try and take it for a dead set serious series. It is basic and straight forward. Nothing too complex about nor is there anything really boring about it. 
It follows a simplistic storyline about a Student President who works as a Maid for a maid cafe in secret and gets found out by one of the hearthrobs of the school. Simple no? What amazed me about this, is just how muchthey expanded on it. Little bit of action, little of romance and comedy that came in a package tied in a bow. 


Sure, you may see a repetitive streak of "chase and save" from Usui (Male MC) but that's the fun. I say it all the time - The chasing in romance genres is what makes an anime. The wishing and hoping for them to be together, waiting for a knight in shining armor, waiting for the heroine to be swept off her feet and dramatically fall in love. 


Throughout the series you see minor development on characters and little to no serious dead beat drama but this isn't the type of anime to suggest it. There really is nothing more to say than, it is fun and thoroughly enjoyable. If you are looking for a serious romance or a serious drama then go watch something else, this anime cannot be taken too seriously or you won't enjoy it.
